name: sfchronicle
text: With coronavirus infections surging, public school teachers in San Jose are resisting plans to get kids and teachers back into physical classrooms as early as Aug. 12, saying that the effort could jeopardize teachers’ health. https://t.co/iRXz34T1gj

name: sfchronicle
text:
Could your family survive on $1,200 a month? @RachelSwan tells the story of a family of 7 trying to survive the financial devastation of the coronavirus: https://t.co/RqVd3fl5IS 

#SFHomelessProject

name: sfchronicle
text: The Oakland A’s will dedicate one section of fan cardboard cutouts toward benefiting the ALS CURE Project, a charity started by Athletics outfielder Stephen Piscotty and his family after Piscotty’s mother died of ALS two years ago. https://t.co/vpcZC3keER

name: sfchronicle
text:
Photos of the Month: Protests over police violence, Class of 2020 graduates, S.F. celebrates Pride and the Golden State Killer pleads guilty. 

See more: https://t.co/fLefdEY5RC https://t.co/1f5r1SvxDm

name: sfchronicle
text: In 2020, "Hamilton" is getting a second look. Activists and @Lin_Manuel himself acknowledge criticisms of the blockbuster musical: https://t.co/374v2mrSLr

name: sfchronicle
text: Manager Gabe Kapler wants to infuse a competition and urgency into summer camp with less than two weeks to the season opener. He got what he wished for in an intrasquad game Saturday that had the feel of a game, minus fans. https://t.co/JOYDagrhdX

name: sfchronicle
text: When people with H-1B skilled-work visas are laid off, they have 60 days to find a comparable new job or leave the country. Thousands of international workers now face this challenge. https://t.co/nFVOeKA7kZ https://t.co/pr1lYXJJ9o

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/z6RpOjtisP

name: sfchronicle
text:
For one San Francisco man, being newly homeless at 77 was already a nightmare —and then the pandemic hit. https://t.co/oMS8StU7gq

#SFHomelessProject

name: sfchronicle
text:
Why does the Bay Area have such an acute homelessness crisis? For the past two years, we asked Chronicle readers to submit questions, and received more than 700 submissions. Here are our answers: https://t.co/GBf8lTsiml

#SFHomelessProject

name: sfchronicle
text: California now has seen more than 7,000 deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, with 7,026 people across the nation’s largest state having lost their lives to the infection as of Sunday morning. The Bay Area has accounted for 641 of those fatalities. https://t.co/zAm94neEgi https://t.co/EBx47w0Pnk

name: sfchronicle
text: Miss fair food this summer? These state and county fairs are bringing staples like tri-tip, corn dogs and monstrous turkey legs online, as well as drive-in movies and concerts in the COVID-19 era: https://t.co/RWGPhTbfwT

name: sfchronicle
text: The coronavirusis is now being defined by disparities in income and race, Bay Area data show. Cases in Alameda County increased nearly five times more rapidly in low-income communities than in high-income ones, according to a Chronicle analysis. https://t.co/N7LFHygXpR https://t.co/ZEwVYq7lXZ

name: sfchronicle
text: U.S. Surgeon Gen. Jerome Adams said Sunday the U.S. can reverse course on the coronavirus outbreaks, and “turn this thing around in just two to three weeks if everyone does their part." https://t.co/KZEKDrmQUD https://t.co/0j0InTjRqB

name: sfchronicle
text: The Chronicle analyzed data showing the daily number of confirmed coronavirus cases in each ZIP code since March in Alameda County — the only Bay Area county that publishes such time-stamped information on infections. https://t.co/2pnlikNP4j https://t.co/u6hP6x8IDr

name: sfchronicle
text: Florida shattered the record for a single-day recording by any state of new coronavirus infections on Sunday, announcing 15,299 cases. The record came as Disney World Resort officially reopened its Magic Kingdom and Animal Kingdom in Orlando. https://t.co/OvbuS0NZJh https://t.co/Y6ha2qO7tk

name: sfchronicle
text:
Bay Area suburbs have seen exponential increases in homeless populations in recent years. What's behind the surge? 

Read more from the #SFHomelessProject: https://t.co/w6VapU2kDz https://t.co/GHVwbkIkB4

name: sfchronicle
text: High-speed collision in Santa Rosa kills 2, injures 3.  https://t.co/0o1LKGpXg4 https://t.co/YHT9muqSkh

name: sfchronicle
text: After months of insisting that the Republican National Convention go on in August despite the pandemic, President Trump is slowly coming to accept it will not be the four-night infomercial for reelection he had anticipated, the Associated Press reports. https://t.co/IGTzwG0TX3 https://t.co/4S7vIimZH3

name: sfchronicle
text: As President Trump has strayed from the advice of public health experts, the White House has moved to sideline Dr. Anthony Fauci, largely keeping him out of the Oval Office even as coronavirus infections surge across America, the Washington Post reports. https://t.co/Tj6G9UzDLp https://t.co/kGA8V941Tq

name: sfchronicle
text: We want to hear your thoughts on our new Throughline series. What changes in the Bay Area would you like to see? Let us know here: https://t.co/HIbAJgs68B

name: sfchronicle
text: Sacramento County added another 150 new cases of the coronavirus to its tally as of Sunday morning, continuing its triple-digit daily increases for a total of 5,489 cases to date. https://t.co/sVXmf7PTFZ https://t.co/tda9sVMH04

name: sfchronicle
text:
The number of Californians hospitalized with COVID-19 stood at 6,322 on Saturday, the state’s health data shows, a slight dip from the previous day and the first daily drop since June 18.  
https://t.co/4fPI6hjtdF https://t.co/DDDTcxZVqn

name: sfchronicle
text:
Contra Costa County reported another 56 coronavirus cases on Sunday, bringing its total cases so far to 4,661. The latest daily increase was notably less than the triple-digit daily hikes the county has seen this month.  
https://t.co/0Qza7iB9VH https://t.co/tWMvBgGXS0
